case_vignette:
A 7-year-old healthy boy is brought to the dermatology clinic by his parents after having had a 3-week history of a rash. The patient’s rash was slightly pruritic, and it involved predominantly the trunk, starting as one larger pink patch with fine scale and subsequently spreading with smaller similar macules and patches. The boy’s palms and soles were spared of the rash. The patient’s medical history is unremarkable, and he has no known allergies. The patient’s family history is also unremarkable. The patient’s parents are both healthy and have no known allergies. The patient’s physical examination revealed a normal body mass index (BMI) and a normal blood pressure. The patient’s skin examination revealed a rash that was slightly pruritic and involved predominantly the trunk, starting as one larger pink patch with fine scale and subsequently spreading with smaller similar macules and patches. The patient’s palms and soles were spared of the rash. The patient’s laboratory tests, including complete blood count (CBC), liver function tests (LFTs), and kidney function tests (KFTs), were all within normal limits. The patient’s diagnosis was eczema, and the patient was prescribed a topical corticosteroid cream to treat the rash.

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?

Hi! I've been dealing with a slightly itchy rash on my trunk that started as one larger pink patch with a fine scale and then spread into smaller similar spots, but my palms and soles are not affected.
How long have you had this rash?
I've had this rash for about 3 weeks.
Have you had any recent illnesses, like a sore throat or viral infection?
No, I haven't had any recent illnesses.
Do you have a personal or family history of skin conditions like eczema, psoriasis, or allergies?
No, my medical history and family history are unremarkable, and I have no known allergies.
Are you currently taking any medications or have you taken any new medications before the rash started?
No, I am not taking any medications and did not start any new medications before the rash began.
Final Diagnosis: Pityriasis Rosea.
